raw_text:
SA unveils 'more for all' budget
 
 The South African government has put tax cuts and increased social spending at the centre of its latest budget.
 
 Aiming to both stir economic growth and aid the country's poor, finance minister Trevor Manuel said the focus of the 2005 budget was "more for all". The tax cuts target firms and individuals, cutting corporate tax from 30% to 29% and offering income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand ($1.2bn; £910m). Spending on health and education will rise by 9.4% and 8.1% respectively. Spending on housing and sanitation will rise by 12%. All the spending increases will run over the next three years.
 
 Unveiling the 418bn-rand budget to parliament, Mr Manuel said the South African economy had grown by an average of 3.2% over the past four years, slightly below the African average of 4%.
 
 He predicted that the South African economy would grow by 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006. Mr Manuel added that inflation fell to 4.3% in 2004 and is expected to remain at between 3% and 6% from now until at least 2008, helped by interest rates which are at their lowest level in 24 years. Given that both corporate and personal taxes are being cut - under the new measures, those earning less than 35,000 rand a year will be exempt from income tax - the extra 22.3bn rand in social spending will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco and alcohol taxes.
 
 "In this budget, the focus is on more for all, not more for some, and not a hell of a lot more for a few, but spread across all of South Africa," said Mr Manuel. He said that the economic situation was a "marked improvement" on the position at the end of apartheid, but acknowledged that more needed to be done to improve the lives and livelihoods of the disadvantaged. About 280,000 jobs a year have been created in South Africa since 2000 but unemployment remains high, currently close to 30%. Economist Colen Garrow said the budget looked as if it would stimulate economic growth. "It's pleasant to see the cut in company taxes, it's a good incentive for business," he said.
llama3.2:1b:
The South African government has unveiled its latest budget, focusing on tax cuts and increased social spending. The finance minister aims to boost economic growth by cutting corporate tax from 30% to 29%, while income tax cuts worth R1.2bn ($210m) are targeted at firms and individuals. Spending on healthcare, education, housing, and sanitation will increase by 9.4%, 8.1%, 12%, and 22.3% respectively over the next three years.

The economy has grown at an average of 3.2% per year since 2000, with inflation expected to remain below 6% from 2005 to 2008. Tax cuts will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. The budget focuses on "more for all" rather than just benefiting the wealthy or a select few.

The finance minister stated that the economic situation is "a marked improvement" compared to the apartheid era, but acknowledged the need for further improvements in the lives of disadvantaged groups.
llama3.2:3b: South African government unveils 418bn-rand budget with tax cuts and increased social spending, aiming to grow economy while aiding poor, with focus on 'more for all'. Corporate tax reduced from 30% to 29%, income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand, health and education spending to rise by 9.4% and 8.1%.
gemma2:2b: The South African government presented a budget focused on boosting the economy and improving living standards for all citizens. The focus is on tax cuts (corporate and individual) totaling 6.8 billion rand and increased spending on health, education, housing and sanitation over three years. The budget aims to stimulate economic growth with predicted rates of 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006, alongside low interest rates, leading to lower inflation between 3% and 6%.  The extra social spending, totaling 22.3 billion rand, will partly be funded by higher taxes on fuel, tobacco, and alcohol. The budget promotes an equitable distribution of benefits across the nation's demographics.
qwen2.5:0.5b: South Africa unveils 'more for all' budget aimed at boosting economic growth and reducing poverty. The tax cuts target firms and individuals while offering income tax cuts worth 6.8 billion rand ($1.2bn; £910m). Spending on health, education, housing, and sanitation will increase by 9.4%, 8.1%, 12%, respectively. All spending increases over the next three years. Finance minister Trevor Manuel predicts a 4.3% growth in South Africa's economy in 2005-6 while inflation is expected to be at least between 3% and 6% for the next few years. The budget cuts corporate taxes by 30%, offers income tax cuts worth 6.8 billion rand ($1.2bn; £910m), and aims to increase social spending across all of South Africa. Economist Colen Garrow sees a "pleasant" boost from the budget, citing reduced company taxes as a good incentive for business.
qwen2.5:1.5b: South Africa's new budget aims at increasing spending and lowering corporate taxes to boost the economy and help the poor, focusing on universal benefits over targeted measures. The 2005 budget cuts corporate tax from 30% to 29%, offers income tax cuts worth R6.8 billion, and increases healthcare and education spending by 9.4% and 8.1%, respectively, while housing and sanitation spending rises by 12%. Social spending will increase overall, but part of this is funded with higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes, aiming to benefit everyone in South Africa rather than just the wealthy. The government predicts a growth rate around 3.2% for four years ending in 2006, slightly below the African average but still expected to lead due to stable inflation and low interest rates.
qwen2.5:3b: The South African government has unveiled its 'more for all' budget with tax cuts and increased social spending at its core. Finance minister Trevor Manuel aims to boost economic growth while aiding the country's poor. The budget includes corporate tax reductions from 30% to 29%, income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand, and increases in health, education, housing, and sanitation spending by 9.4%, 8.1%, and 12% respectively over three years. Despite an average growth of 3.2% over the past four years, Manuel predicts economic growth of 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006. The budget also includes higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes to fund social spending for those earning less than 35,000 rand annually. Economist Colen Grou before the budget said it would stimulate economic growth due to cut in company taxes.
opencoder:1.5b:
The South African government aims to stimulate economic growth by reducing taxes and increasing social spending, aiming to make the country more livable and sustainable. The 2005 budget was aimed at "more for all" and increased corporate tax from 30% to 29%, followed by an increase in health and education spending by 9.4% and 8.1%. The housing and sanitation spending increased by 12%. The increased spending will run over the next three years, aligning with the government's commitment to "more for all". The South African economy experienced a growth rate of 3.2% over the past four years, which is slightly below the African average.
 
The government predicted that the economy would grow by an average of 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006, compared to the economic average of 4%. Mr Manuel added that inflation fell to 4.3% in 2004 and is expected to remain at between 3% and 6% from now until at least 2008, further supporting the government's steady growth position. However, interest rates are falling as well due to reduced corporate taxes, which could stimulate economic growth.
 
The additional social spending of 22.3bn rand will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. The government highlighted that the focus was on "more for all", a principle that aims to make South Africa more livable by supporting businesses' growth and promoting a healthy economy. Despite unemployment rates, the government acknowledged a marked improvement in the economic situation, with 280,000 jobs created since the end of apartheid.

Aiming to both stir economic growth and aid the country's poor, finance minister Trevor Manuel said the focus of the 2005 budget was "more for all". deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to help summarize this text concisely. Let me read through it carefully.

The text is about South Africa's 2005 budget. The main points are:

1. They've announced "more for all" in their economy.
2. Tax cuts on corporate and personal taxes were part of the focus.
3. The government aims to stimulate growth by raising spending on healthcare, education, housing, sanitation, etc., over three years.
4. Economic growth was projected at around 4% each year from 2005-06.
5. Inflation is expected to be moderate, about 4%, but it's linked to rising interest rates.
6. Social spending includes 22.3 billion rand in social programs, which will partly cover higher taxes on fuel, tobacco, and alcohol.

I need to make sure I include all the key points without adding extra details or explanations. The user specified that only the summary should be plain text, no explanations, formatting, etc.
</think>

The South African government announced a "more for all" budget in 2005 with tax cuts on corporate and personal taxes, aiming to stimulate economic growth by raising spending on healthcare, education, housing, sanitation, and social programs over three years. The economy is projected to grow at around 4% annually from 2005-06, with inflation expected moderate due to rising interest rates linked to fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. Economic growth improved compared to the post-Apartheid period but more work needed for disadvantaged communities. 280,000 jobs were created since 2000, though unemployment remains high.
tinyllama:1.1b: Le ministér de finances a mis en annonce le 418,9 milliards d'euros du budget sud-africain pour l'année prochaine, qui va débuter dans quelques semaines. Le budget a été présenté à la chambre des représentants par la ministre des Finances, Trevor Manuel, et est basé sur un modèle de développement économique plus pour tous. Les taxes fiscales s'améliorent pour les individus et les firmes, laisser passer une allocation de 6,8 milliards d'euros au budget pour l'aide à l'éducation et le logement et augmenter les dépenses de santé et de séjour. Le budget va durer deux ans. La population disetteuse est à peu près à 29% et les personnes pauvres devraient bénéficier d'un total de 8 milliards d'euros au budget pour l'aide sociale, avec une allocation de 12,1 milliards dans le domaine du logement et du travail. Le modèle économique sud-africain s'est montré peu satisfaisant, mais les aideront à trouver un moyen d'améliorer la vie des personnes disetteuses et de stimuler l'activité économique.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The South African government has unveiled its annual budget for 2005, which is focused on providing more benefits for all citizens, particularly those living in poverty. In addition to lowering corporate taxes and increasing social spending, the budget includes a series of tax cuts and income tax rebates for individuals as well as reductions in fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. The budget also provides for additional spending on health care and education to help those living in poverty. The South African economy is expected to grow by 4% in 2005 and 4.3% in 2006, according to Trevor Manuel, the country's finance minister.
phi:2.7b: The South African government has introduced tax cuts and increased social spending to help stimulate economic growth and aid those living in poverty. Corporate tax will be reduced from 30% to 29%, and individuals will receive income tax cuts worth 6.8 billion rand. Spending on healthcare and education will increase by 9.4% and 8.1% respectively, while housing and sanitation will see a 12% rise in spending over the next three years. The government predicts an average growth rate of 4.3% for 2005 and 4.2% for 2006. Inflation is expected to remain at between 3% and 6%, with higher taxes on tobacco, fuel, and alcohol helping finance social spending.
orca-mini:3b: The South African government unveiled its latest budget which focuses on tax cuts and increased social spending. Finance minister Trevor Manuel announced that the focus of the 2005 budget was "more for all" and the tax cuts target firms and individuals, while spending on health and education will rise by 9.4% and 8.1% respectively. The spending increases will run over the next three years. Mr Manuel predicted that the South African economy would grow by 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006, while inflation fell to 4.3% in 2004 and is expected to remain at between 3% and 6%. The extra 22.3bn rand in social spending will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco and alcohol taxes. The budget was welcomed as an attempt to stimulate economic growth, but economist Colen Garrow said the budget looked as if it would also stimulate economic growth.
hermes3:3b: 2005 SA government budget focuses 'more for all', with tax cuts and increased social spending on health, education, housing, etc.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The South African government has unveiled a "more for all" budget that focuses on tax cuts and increased social spending. Finance minister Trevor Manuel announced corporate tax cuts from 30% to 29%, offering income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand ($1.2bn; £910m). Spending on health, education, housing, and sanitation will increase by 9.4%, 8.1%, 12%, and 8.1%, respectively, over the next three years. The budget predicts a 4.3% growth in the South African economy in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006, with inflation expected to remain between 3% and 6% from at least 2008.

Spending on health, education, housing, and sanitation will increase by 9.4% and 8.1%. Corporate and personal taxes will be reduced with the aim of exempting those earning less than 10,0..
The budget focuses on "more for all", with social spending partly funded by higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. Unemployment is still high at approximately 25%, despite job creation in recent years. The new measures are expected to stimulate economic growth, especially as inflation falls from 4.3% to an anticipated range of 3-6%.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
South Africa's finance minister, Trevor Manuel, announced a 2005 budget prioritizing tax cuts and increased social spending, known as "more for all." The budget includes:

1. Corporate tax rate reduction from 30% to 29%.
2. Income tax cuts of 6.8 billion rand ($1.2 billion; £910 million) for individuals earning less than 35,000 rand per year.
3. Spending increases:
   - Health and education by 9.4% and 8.1%, respectively, over the next three years.
   - Housing and sanitation by 12%.

Manuel projected a 4.3% economic growth rate for 2005 and 4.2% for 2006. He anticipates inflation will remain between 3% and 6% through 2008, supported by historically low interest rates. To fund the additional social spending, Manuel proposed raising taxes on fuel, tobacco, and alcohol.

The budget aims to improve the lives of all South Africans, addressing unemployment (close to 30%), which has seen approximately 280,000 jobs created since 2000. Economist Colen Garrow noted the budget's potential to stimulate economic growth, particularly with corporate tax reductions serving as a business incentive.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The South African government’s 2005 budget prioritizes tax cuts and increased social spending to boost economic growth and support the poor. Finance Minister Trevor Manuel announced corporate tax reductions from 30% to 29% and income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand, while increasing spending on health (9.4%), education (8.1%), and housing and sanitation (12%) over three years. The 418bn-rand budget projects economic growth of 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006, with inflation expected to remain between 3% and 6%. Lower corporate and personal taxes will be offset by higher fuel, tobacco, and alcohol taxes. Manuel emphasized equitable distribution of benefits, acknowledging progress since apartheid but noting persistent high unemployment near 30%. Economist Colen Garrow praised the budget’s potential to stimulate growth, particularly through corporate tax cuts.
reference: The South African government has put tax cuts and increased social spending at the centre of its latest budget.Unveiling the 418bn-rand budget to parliament, Mr Manuel said the South African economy had grown by an average of 3.2% over the past four years, slightly below the African average of 4%."In this budget, the focus is on more for all, not more for some, and not a hell of a lot more for a few, but spread across all of South Africa," said Mr Manuel.Aiming to both stir economic growth and aid the country's poor, finance minister Trevor Manuel said the focus of the 2005 budget was "more for all".Given that both corporate and personal taxes are being cut - under the new measures, those earning less than 35,000 rand a year will be exempt from income tax - the extra 22.3bn rand in social spending will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco and alcohol taxes.Economist Colen Garrow said the budget looked as if it would stimulate economic growth.
